cons:
VPs and Senior Directors move often, creating inconsistency for brand strategy. New leaders each want to put their "mark" on a brand, and often abandon the strategy of their predecessor to do so, causing a lot of fire drills, rework, and waste. But more than anything, it dilutes our brand equities. It's hard to stay focused on a brand purpose when that purpose is constantly changing.

The way the company is structured (separate P&Ls for snacks vs. beverages vs. Gatorade, etc) might work for Wall Street, but encourages internal competition instead of collaboration. We could be stronger faster and better if we were incentivized to work across our categories and if we all understood the role each brand and product brings to the whole of PepsiCo.

review_title: Great people, but politics and opportunities prevent growth
pros: The people at this company are some of the kindest, supportive, and most cooperative people that I have ever had the pleasure of working with. Everyone is always looking to make things work better and solve problems.
cons:
HR here is very difficult to work with. Any time it comes to compensation or promotions, the company tries to have as little interaction with the employee as possible. You are essentially told your salary with no room to negotiate.

Rules are put into place to keep you at a role for certain periods of time however, these rules are unevenly enforced and allow certain people to advance faster than others.
Advice to Management
When I first joined Pepsi, I was extended an offer and was low-balled. I had received close to Christmas time. When I decided to counteroffer, HR came back to me and told me that there were too many people out for the holidays and that I would not be able to negotiate my salary. Having no other options at the time, I took the offer I was given.

While in the company, I found that employees that were extended offers through the intern program (a program that I was not a part of) were given roughly $10k more for the same position than what "external hires" were extended. I routinely pointed out this inequity to HR and was ignored or told that the salary I was getting was competitive with market rates. 

After spending 18 months in a role, an employee has the opportunity to move to a new role. However, this rule was broken frequently based on the circumstances but it's based on how willing the manager is to fight for you regardless of your qualifications. Once again, the company shows it's inequity.

The company has really talented, passionate people. The culture of the company is fun and supportive. But there is so much arbitrary inequity in pay and opportunity that drives people away. As a result, it is very difficult to stay motivated.

To start, be upfront about business needs and potentially long hours. The aim should be to retain workers who are content with all realistic expectations, even if it means scaring other candidates off.

Finally, incorporate a formal training process. Current training consists of shadowing for six hours, and then they're on their own to strikeout. Give new hires one designated mentor for the first week to help build confidence through hands-on practice and guidance. Having one teacher will help to keep new hires from becoming overwhelmed since everybody has their way of doing things. It's easy for some trainees to feel like they're doing nothing right sometimes because of this, even if they have made notable improvements. Throughout the second week, touch base on factors such as what the trainees can improve on and what they've done well.

In conclusion, don't tell candidates to expect consistent eight hour nights if that isn't realistic, and make the first two weeks on the job manageable and controlled. Aim to retain with honesty and attentiveness.
